variant.question: An Operator takes disciplinary action against a pilot, claiming that he/she violated the operating procedures, landing with insufficient fuel on board. The pilot demonstrates that he/she had made a mistake in writing down the number of fuel gallons when completing the technical log after flight, and that the fuel on board after landing was actually well within the operational limits. The Operator's disciplinary decision is to suspend the pilot from work for 10 days. Which of the following statements is correct, as regards the Operator's safety culture?

options.text: The Operator does NOT apply "just culture" principles: to foster trust and collaboration. This type of unintended slip should be reported and discussed to prevent further errors, but should NOT be punished.

The Operator applies "Just Culture" principles, fairly punishing negligent behaviour as a form of positive control. This can motivate employees to be more careful before acting and promote awareness of risks.

The Operator demonstrates an effective concern towards safety, considering negligent behaviour as unacceptable. Negligence indicates a lack of awareness of risks and hazards, which can lead to a reduction in flight safety.
Punishing an employee for making an error is an example of bad management, in a "just culture" environment errors and violations should NOT be punished, in order to promote an atmosphere of trust.

variant.question:
The World Health Organisation (WHO) is an organisation of the United Nations founded in **1948** and based in Geneva. It strives for the best achievable level of health for a people worldwide, whereat health means a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being. Among others, the WHO has conducted a study on alcoholism, its signs and symptoms, risk groups and the effects on the addicted persons’ lives.
State which of the following persons, according to the WHO definition, is most likely to be an alcoholic.

options.text: A middle-aged man in a highly regarded job drinks greater amounts of a special brand of whiskey on weekends and holidays. He will drive great distances at any time to buy a bottle of whiskey and revert to alternatives when his brand is not available. His tolerance towards alcohol has increased over the years, along with the average amount he drinks. He laughs off concerns voiced about health effects of his alcohol consumption.

A widow woman drinks a glass of wine almost every evening, preferring quality dry red wine from Italy. She has made it a ritual to prepare her drink in one of the wine glasses that have been her wedding gift and raising her glass to a photograph of her deceased husband before drinking. When there is no wine left in her apartment, she reverts to eating great amounts of chocolate and buys a new bottle of wine on her next shopping tour. She justifies her consumption with the positive effect on the arteries.

A young woman has always been drinking moderate amounts of alcohol, preferably sparkling wine mixed with orange juice, on social occasions. She has just recently discovered that she has finally become pregnant, and is in pleasant anticipation of the time ahead. She decides to drink half a glass of champagne on a New Year’s Eve party, despite the warnings of two friends partying with her that alcohol could have adverse effects on her baby.

A teenager regularly drinks great amounts of alcohol in company of peers about twice a month, especially on bigger events, but also on occasions such a birthday parties. He has been hospitalised with alcohol intoxication previously, and his closer friends regularly keep an eye on his consumption once he has passed a certain threshold.

variant.question: Which of the following statements are correct regarding alcohol consumption? - The blood alcohol level during a flight duty period or whilst on standby must always be 0.0 per thousand. - No alcohol must be consumed less than 8 hours prior to the specified beginning of the flight duty period. - The blood alcohol level at the start of the flight duty period must not exceed 0.2 per thousand. - Alcohol consumption during a flight duty period or whilst on standby must be restricted so that the blood alcohol level may never exceed 0.2 per thousand.

In an abnormal situation the pilot has an apparently correct explanation for the problem. The chance that he/she now ignores or devalues other relevant information, not fitting into his/her mental picture is..

options.text: not possible since correct training should have eliminated this problem.

variant.question: The cocktail party effect is:

options.text: the ability to pick up relevant information unintentionally.
the tendency to believe information that reinforces our mental model of the world.
the ability to drink too much at social gathering.
the tendency not to perceive relevant information.

variant.question: The Cocktail Party Effect is associated with
An experienced pilot has just started to work for a new airline with different SOPs and is completing a type-rating for a new aircraft type. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.text: The pilot has an increased risk for slips and lapses if the new aircraft type is very similar to his previous one.
The pilot has a reduced risk for slips and lapses if the new aircraft type is very similar to his previous one.
The pilot has an increased risk for slips and lapses if the new aircraft type is very different from his previous one.
The pilot has a reduced risk for slips and lapses if the new aircraft type is very different from his previous one.

variant.question: During the cruise, at night, when the workload is low, it is recommended that..

options.text: the lighting in the cockpit be increased in order to prevent low vigilance.
only those instruments that are vital to flying the aircraft be lit in order to avoid dividing one’s attention.
the lighting in the cockpit be dimmed in order to reduce visual fatigue.
the lighting in the cockpit be dimmed in order to prevent low vigilance.
